journal-title-group.journal-title: Arion: A Journal of Humanities and the Classics

title-group.article-title: Redeeming the Text: The Validity of Comparisons of Classical and Postclassical Literature (A View from Britain)

ref-list.title: Short Bibliography of Works Relevant to Reeption Theory

ref.mixed-citation: Beer, Gillian. Arguing with the Past: Essays in Narrative From Woolf to Sidney. Routledge, London and New York, 1989, introduction, pp. 1-11.
Bloom, Harold. The Anxiety of Influence: A Theory of Poetry. Oxford University Press, Oxford, 1973.

Fish, Stanley. Doing What Comes Naturally: Change, Rhetoric and the Practice of Theory in Literary and Legal Studies. Clarendon Press, Oxford, 1989.
—. Is There a Text in This Class? The Authority of Interpretive Communi- ties. Harvard University Press, Cambridge, Mass., 1980.
Gadamer, Hans-Georg. Truth and Method, trs. G. Barden and J. Cumming. Sheed and Ward, London, 1975.
Holub, Robert C. Reception Theory: A Critical Introduction. Methuen (New Accents), London and New York, 1984.
Hoy, David Couzens. The Critical Circle: Literature, History, and Philosophical Hermeneutics. University of California Press, Berkeley, Los Angeles, London, 1978.
Iser, Wolfgang. The Act of Reading: A Theory of Aesthetic Response. Johns Hop- kins University Press, Baltimore and London, 1978.
Jauss, Hans Robert. Toward an Aesthetic of Reception, tr. Timothy Bahti. Har- vester, Brighton, 1982.
Kermode, Frank. The Classic. Faber, London, 1975.
—. The Genesis of Secrecy: On the Interpretation of Narrative. Harvard University Press, Cambridge, Mass., and London, 1979 (on biblical hermeneutics).
Lewis, C. S. An Experiment in Criticism. Cambridge University Press, 1961.
Michaels, W. B. "Saving the Text: Reference and Belief." Modern Language Notes 93 (1978), pp. 771-793.
Mitter, Partha. "Can We Ever Understand Alien Cultures?" Comparative Criti- cism 9 (1987), pp. 3-34.
Peradotto, John. "Texts and Unrefracted Facts: Philology, Hermeneutics and Semiotics." Arethusa 16 (1983), pp. 15-33.

For reception theory in action see, for example, George Steiner, Antigones, Clarendon Press, Oxford, 1984, or the essays in my Ovid Renewed: Ovidian influences on literature and art from the Middle Ages to the twentieth century, Cambridge University Press, 1988.
